Typedef Documentation

typedef void TgmTelegram
 

An opeaque structure used by telegram library

Enumeration Type Documentation

enum TimLibCcvMask
 

Each PTIM equipment has a set of current control values. The values to be read or written should have their bit set in the CcvMask.

Enumeration values:
TimLibCcvMaskENABLE  Enable of Disable output field
TimLibCcvMaskSTART  Counter Start field
TimLibCcvMaskMODE  Counter Mode field
TimLibCcvMaskCLOCK  Counter clock field
TimLibCcvMaskPWIDTH  Pulse Width in 25ns steps field
TimLibCcvMaskDELAY  Delay field
TimLibCcvMaskOMASK  Outputs to Lemo field
TimLibCcvMaskPOLARITY  Polarity field TTL/TTL_BAR
TimLibCcvMaskCTIM  CTIM equipment number field
TimLibCcvMaskPAYLOAD  Payload field
TimLibCcvMaskMACHINE  Telegram machine field
TimLibCcvMaskGRNUM  Telegram group number field
TimLibCcvMaskGRVAL  Telegram group value

enum TimLibClass
 

There are 3 classes of interrupt that can be connected to, hardware, PTIM equipment, CTIM equipment or direct hardware.

Enumeration values:
TimLibClassHARDWARE  Class is direct hardware connection
TimLibClassCTIM  A Ctim timing object carried by an event on the cable
TimLibClassPTIM  A PTIM timing object implemented on a counter

enum TimLibClock
 

These clocks on the CTR cards are phase locked on to UTC time with a short term RMS jitter of 100ps. The peak to peak is better than one nano second. On the TG8 the jitter is horrible 500ns, and the many clocks are not available, namley 10, 40MHz, and CHAINED.

Enumeration values:
TimLibClock1KHZ  The 1KHZ CTrain clock from the 01 events
TimLibClock10MHZ  Divided down 40MHZ phase synchronous with 1KHZ
TimLibClock40MHZ  Recovered 40MHZ by the PLL from the data edges
TimLibClockEXT1  External clock one
TimLibClockEXT2  External clock two
TimLibClockCHAINED  The output of the previous counter is the clock
TimLibCLOCKS  The number of possible clock sources

enum TimLibCstStat
 

Full CTR card status bit definitions The CTR card only has a lot of extra status information in a dedicated status block

Enumeration values:
TimLibCstStatCTRXE  Beam Energy extension is present (Energy on VME-P2)
TimLibCstStatCTRXI  IO extension is present (Can use as an IO register
TimLibCstStatV1_PCB  PCB version 1 (Old hardware: No ID chip: Totempole
TimLibCstStatV2_PCB  PCB version 2 (ID chip, tristate outputs)
TimLibCstStatS1  External start 1 value (If IO extension present)
TimLibCstStatS2  External start 2 value (If IO extension present)
TimLibCstStatX1  External clock 1 value (If IO extension present)
TimLibCstStatX2  External clock 2 value (If IO extension present)
TimLibCstStatO1  Lemo output 1 state (If IO extension present)
TimLibCstStatO2  Lemo output 2 state (If IO extension present)
TimLibCstStatO3  Lemo output 3 state (If IO extension present)
TimLibCstStatO4  Lemo output 4 state (If IO extension present)
TimLibCstStatO5  Lemo output 5 state (If IO extension present)
TimLibCstStatO6  Lemo output 6 state (If IO extension present)
TimLibCstStatO7  Lemo output 7 state (If IO extension present)
TimLibCstStatO8  Lemo output 8 state (If IO extension present)
TimLibCstStatIDOkP  PCB ID chip is present
TimLibCstStatDebugHistory  Debug History Mode switched ON (All events logged)
TimLibCstStatUtcPllEnabled  Utc Pll enable state (0=Brutal 1=Slow lock)
TimLibCstStatExtendedMemory  Extended status and diagnostics memory present
TimLibCstStatTemperatureOk  Temperature Sensor installed

enum TimLibDevice
 

There are currently many different devices that can receive events from the timing cable, or the controls netwrok. Each device offers device specific features. The NETWORK device is implemented accross DTM and uses UDP packets, it offers telegram access and restricted event subscriptions for synchronization of application programs.

Enumeration values:
TimLibDevice_ANY  Use whatever is available
TimLibDevice_CTR_PCI  Timing events are comming from a PCI CTR
TimLibDevice_CTR_VME  Timing events are comming from a VME CTR
TimLibDevice_TG8_CPS  Timing events are comming from a CPS TG8
TimLibDevice_TG8_SPS  Timing events are comming from a SPS TG8
TimLibDevice_NETWORK  Timing events arrive on the netwrok UDP
TimLibDEVICES  Number of different timing event sources

enum TimLibEnable
 

Enable states for counters. When directly controling a counter, its possible to also control the Bus Interrupt behaviour. For PTIM objects the bus interrupt bit is controled by the driver. The enables behave like bits as well as indexes.

Enumeration values:
TimLibEnableNOOUT  No bits means do nothing
TimLibEnableOUT  Bit 0 means out
TimLibEnableBUS  Bit 1 means bus
TimLibEnableOUTBUS  Both bits means bus and out
TimLibENABLES  Number of output states

enum TimLibError
 

On some cards like the Tg8, delays are 16 bits, on the CTR they are up to 32 bits.On the Tg8 the PulseWidth is always 1us and can not be modified etc etc etc. This type deals with the errors that can arrise when using the timing library.

Enumeration values:
TimLibErrorSUCCESS  All went OK, No error
TimLibErrorHARDWARE  Invalid TimLibHardware value for this device
TimLibErrorSTART  Invalid TimLibStart value for this device
TimLibErrorMODE  Invalid TimLibMode value for this device
TimLibErrorCLOCK  Invalid TimLibClock value for this device
TimLibErrorPWIDTH  Invalid PulseWidth value for this device
TimLibErrorDELAY  Invalid Delay value for this device
TimLibErrorNO_REMOTE  Invalid remote command value for this device
TimLibErrorMODULE  Invalid module number, not installed
TimLibErrorCOUNTER  Invalid counter number for this module
TimLibErrorPTIM  Invalid PTIM equipment number
TimLibErrorCTIM  Invalid CTIM equipment number
TimLibErrorBLOCKED  That operation is blocked, its not permitted
TimLibErrorPPM  PPM is not supported on this device type
TimLibErrorMACHINE  Invalid machine for this PTIM object
TimLibErrorGROUP  Invalid group number/value for PTIM object
TimLibErrorINIT  Library has not been initialized
TimLibErrorOPEN  Can't open a driver file handle, fatal
TimLibErrorCONNECT  Can't connect to that object
TimLibErrorWAIT  No connections to wait for
TimLibErrorTIMEOUT  Timeout in wait
TimLibErrorQFLAG  Queue flag must be set 0, queueing is needed
TimLibErrorIO  Unspecified IO error
TimLibErrorNOT_IMP  Not implemented on this device
TimLibErrorEXISTS  Equipment already exists
TimLibErrorNOMEM  Out of resource space or memory
TimLibErrorNOT_ENAB  Module has not been enabled
TimLibErrorNOT_FOUND  Couldn't find a cycle for that time stamp
TimLibErrorSTRING  Cycle string did not specify an actual cycle
TimLibERRORS  Total errors

enum TimLibHardware
 

This enumeration describes hardware interrupt sources. This class of connection is useful for a FESA aquisition task which could log the times of any output or incomming CTIM. In addition the 1Hz and 1KHz interrupt connections can be useful.

Enumeration values:
TimLibHardwareCTIM  Any connected CTIM interrupt
TimLibHardwareCOUNTER_1  Any counter 1 output
TimLibHardwareCOUNTER_2  Any counter 2 output
TimLibHardwareCOUNTER_3  Any counter 3 output
TimLibHardwareCOUNTER_4  Any counter 4 output
TimLibHardwareCOUNTER_5  Any counter 5 output
TimLibHardwareCOUNTER_6  Any counter 6 output
TimLibHardwareCOUNTER_7  Any counter 7 output
TimLibHardwareCOUNTER_8  Any counter 8 output
TimLibHardwarePLL_ITERATION  Phase locked loop iteration
TimLibHardwareGMT_EVENT_IN  Any incomming timing frame
TimLibHardware1HZ  Tne one second UTC time pulse
TimLibHardware1KHZ  One Kilo Hertz
TimLibHardwareMATCHED  Incomming event trigger matched

enum TimLibLemo
 

Counter IO Lemo Connectors

Enumeration values:
TimLibLemoOUT_1  Output: Lemo Counter 1
TimLibLemoOUT_2  Output: Lemo Counter 2
TimLibLemoOUT_3  Output: Lemo Counter 3
TimLibLemoOUT_4  Output: Lemo Counter 4
TimLibLemoOUT_5  Output: Lemo Counter 5
TimLibLemoOUT_6  Output: Lemo Counter 6
TimLibLemoOUT_7  Output: Lemo Counter 7
TimLibLemoOUT_8  Output: Lemo Counter 8
TimLibLemoXST_1  Input: Lemo External Start 1
TimLibLemoXST_2  Input: Lemo External Start 2
TimLibLemoXCL_1  Input: Lemo External Clock 1
TimLibLemoXCL_2  Input: Lemo External Clock 2

enum TimLibMode
 

In burst mode, the stop can be EXT2 start, or the output of the next counter if the start is chained_stop. Multiple start permits many starts for only one load. In Multiple Burst many bursts can be made for a single load.

Enumeration values:
TimLibModeNORMAL  One load, one start and one output mode
TimLibModeMULTIPLE  One load, multiple starts, multiple outputs
TimLibModeBURST  Like MULTIPLE, but terminated by external start two
TimLibModeMULT_BURST  Both mode 1 & 2 = Multiple bursts
TimLibMODES  There are 4 possible counter configuration modes

enum TimLibOutput
 

The output routing mask specifies which signals are sent to which of the output connectors. N.B. On some cards (CTRP/I) there are more counters on the card (8) than there are front pannel connectors (4). Each counter 1..8, owns a physical output channel leading to a front pannel connector. The output mask for a given counter selects what signals are assigned to the counters output connector.

Enumeration values:
TimLibOutputCTIM  Any connected CTIM interrupt
TimLibOutputCNTR_1  Counter 1 output
TimLibOutputCNTR_2  Counter 2 output
TimLibOutputCNTR_3  Counter 3 output
TimLibOutputCNTR_4  Counter 4 output
TimLibOutputCNTR_5  Counter 5 output
TimLibOutputCNTR_6  Counter 6 output
TimLibOutputCNTR_7  Counter 7 output
TimLibOutputCNTR_8  Counter 8 output
TimLibOutput40MHZ  40MHz clock bit
TimLibOutputEXT1  Ext-1 clock bit
TimLibOutputEXT2  Ext-2 clock bit

enum TimLibPolarity
 

The polarity of a counter output.

Enumeration values:
TimLibPolarityTTL_BAR  Negative TTL Bar
TimLibPolarityTTL  Posative TTL

enum TimLibRemote
 

Counters can be directly controlled from the RT task. These are the possible remote control commands that can be used in direct control.

Enumeration values:
TimLibRemoteLOAD  Load the counter with a new set of control values
TimLibRemoteSTOP  Kill counter no matter what its state
TimLibRemoteSTART  Start the counter, the startREMOTE must be set
TimLibRemoteOUT  Make output on output pin, counter not disturbed
TimLibRemoteBUS  Make a bus interrupt now, counter not disturbed

enum TimLibStart
 

The sources of start in a counter. The chained_stop starts from the output of the previous counter and stops from the output of the next counter. This is sometimes needed when using burst mode.

Enumeration values:
TimLibStartNORMAL  The next millisecond tick starts the counter
TimLibStartEXT1  The counter uses external start number one
TimLibStartEXT2  The counter uses external start number two
TimLibStartCHAINED  The output of the previous counter is the start
TimLibStartSELF  The output of this counter is the start (Divide)
TimLibStartREMOTE  The counter waits for a remote start, see later
TimLibStartPPS  The counter waits for the PPS
TimLibStartCHAINED_STOP  The counter is started by previous and stopped by next
TimLibSTARTS  The number of possible counter starts

enum TimLibStatus
 

Status of timing receiver, for Tg8 modules the PLL bit is set OK

Enumeration values:
TimLibStatusGMT_OK  Timing being recieved
TimLibStatusPLL_OK  PLL locked
TimLibStatusSELF_OK  Self test OK
TimLibStatusENABLED  Timing Reception enabled
TimLibStatusBUS_OK  No Bus Errors detected

Function Documentation

TimLibError TimLibConnect (  TimLibClass  iclss,
unsigned long  equip,
unsigned long  module
) 
 

Connect to an interrupt. If you are connecting to either a CTIM interrupt or to a hardware interrupt, you may need to specify on which device the interrupt should be connected. This is achieved by the module parameter. If the module is zero, the system will decide which device to use, otherwise module contains a value between 1 and the number of installed timing receiver cards. For PTIM objects the module parameter must be set to zero or the real module on which the PTIM object is implemented. On PTIM objects the module is implicit.

Parameters:
iclss Class of interrupt
equip Equipment or hardware mask
module Module on which to do the connect
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibConnectPayload (  unsigned long  ctim,
unsigned long  payload,
unsigned long  module
) 
 

Connect to a CTIM with a specified payload

Parameters:
ctim The ctim ID you want to connect to
payload The 16 bit bayload in a long
module The module number 1..n of the timing receiver card
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibCreateCtimObject (  unsigned long  ctim,
unsigned long  eventcode
) 
 

Create a new CTIM object. If a payload is to be used for this event be sure to set the low 16-Bits to 0xFFFF

Parameters:
ctim The CTIM equipment number you want to create
eventcode The eventcode like this 0x211c0101 or 0x211CFFFF
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibCreatePtimObject (  unsigned long  ptim,
unsigned long  module,
unsigned long  counter,
unsigned long  dimension
) 
 

Create a new PTIM object, the CCV settings will be defaulted, see the TimLib.h include file TimLibCcvDEFAULT definitions. The setteings you need can then be modified using the TimLibSet function.

Unfortunately because the SPS TG8 driver uses multiple file descriptors, one per installed module, then in this particular case, this routine will return only that of module 1.

Parameters:
ptim The PTIM equipment number you want to create
module The module on which to create it
counter The counter that the PTIM uses
dimension The PPM dimension, usually 1 or 24
Returns:
TimLibError

char* TimLibErrorToString (  TimLibError  error  ) 
 

Convert a TimLibError into a string. The returned char pointer is either NULL if the supplied error is out of range, or it points to a static string contained on the library routines heap. You must copy the string if you need to be sure it is not overwritten. Obviously this routine is therfore not thread safe, but you don't need to free allocated memory thus avoiding potential memory leaks.

Parameters:
error The error code whose string you want
Returns:
Static pointer to the resulting read only string

TimLibError TimLibFdConnect (  int  fd,
TimLibClass  iclss,
unsigned long  equip,
unsigned long  module
) 
 

For multi-threaded applications, where each thread needs its own filedesc. This is just like the usual connect except you must supply a fd that is open and was obtained from FdInitialize. Should you supply a fd with a bad value the driver will check if it belongs to your process and if it dose it will use it. This may cause unpredictable results.

Parameters:
fd File handle
iclss Class of interrupt
equip Equipment or hardware mask
module Module on which to do the connect
Returns:
TimLibError

int TimLibFdInitialize (  TimLibDevice  device  ) 
 

For multi-threaded applications, each thread needs its own filedesc. This initialize will return a new file descriptor each time it is called. Today the drivers support a maximum of 16 file descriptors so the resource is limited and should be used economically; always call "close(fd)" when the descriptor is no longer needed. In case of errors, a zero is returned.

Parameters:
device The device for which the library is to initialize
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibFdQueue (  int  fd,
unsigned long  qflag,
unsigned long  tmout
) 
 

For multi-threaded applications, where each thread needs its own filedesc. Set queueing On or Off, and the time out value in micro seconds. A timeout value of zero means no time out, you wait for ever.

Parameters:
fd File handle
qflag The Queue Flag 0=>Queue, 1=>NoQueue
tmout The Timeout in microseconds, 0=> No timeout, waits for ever
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibFdWait (  int  fd,
TimLibClass *  iclss,
unsigned long *  equip,
unsigned long *  plnum,
TimLibHardware *  source,
TimLibTime *  onzero,
TimLibTime *  trigger,
TimLibTime *  start,
unsigned long *  ctim,
unsigned long *  payload,
unsigned long *  module,
unsigned long *  missed,
unsigned long *  qsize,
TgmMachine *  machine
) 
 

For multi-threaded applications, where each thread needs its own filedesc. Wait for an interrupt. The parameters are all returned from the call so you can know which interrupt it was that came back. Note, when waiting for a hardware interrupt from either CTIM or from a counter, it is the CTIM or PTIM object that caused the interrupt returned. The telegram will have been read already by the high prioity task get_tgm_tim, be aware of the race condition here, hence payload. This routine is a blocking call, it waits for interrupt or timeout. Any NULL argument is permitted, and no value will be returned.

Parameters:
fd File handle
iclss The class of the interrupt CTIM, PTIM, or hardware
equip The PTIM, CTIM equipment, or hardware mask
plnum If class is PTIM this is the PLS line number
source The hardware source of the interrupt
onzero The time of the interrupt
trigger The arrival time of the event that triggered the action
start The time the start of the counter occured
ctim The CTIM equipment number of the triggering event
payload The payload of the triggering event
module The module number 1..n of the timing receiver card
missed The number of missed events since the last wait
qsize The number of remaining interrupts on the queue
machine The Tgm machine of the trigger event
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibGet (  unsigned long  ptim,
unsigned long  plnum,
unsigned long  grnum,
unsigned long  grval,
TimLibCcvMask *  ccvm,
TimLibCcv *  ccv
) 
 

Get the Ccv of a PTIM equipment. When reading, the valid fields are determined by the module type. Some modules types, eg Tg8 have missing fields in the ccv structure.

Parameters:
ptim The PTIM equipment number whose parameters you want to get
plnum When this is the Ptim Line number 1..n, else 0
grnum The telegram group number or zero if no telegram check needed
grval The telegram group value needed to activate the trigger
ccvm Pointer to a mask which will denote which fields are valid
ccv Pointer to the CCV structure containing the fields read
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibGetCableId (  unsigned long  module,

)

cable The resulting cable Id

)

TimLibError TimLibGetHandle (  int *  fd  ) 
 

In some cases when running a GUI under Linux, say, a file handle to put in a "select" is needed so that one can wait on multiple file handles simultaneously. This routine returns such a handle suitable to check for waiting interrupts. Don not read directly from it, call the wait routine. The queue flag must be on for this to work !!

Parameters:
fd Will be filled with the file descriptor for a select
Returns:
TimLibError

unsigned long TimLibGetQueueSize (   ) 
 

To know if a call to wait will block, this call returns the Queue size. If the size is greater than zero a call to wait will not block and return without waiting. If the qflag is set to NoQueue, zero is allways returned and all calls to wait will block.

Returns:
number of unread items on the queue

char* TimLibGetSpecificInfo (  unsigned long  module  ) 
 

Get specific status information string. This routine returns summary text on the internal state of a timing receiver. The CTR and Tg8 modules provide much useful information on their internal functions that can help diagnose a problem. However as the implementation is very different, the text string returned is module specific, and contains data for hardware specialists only.

Parameters:
module The module on which to create it
Returns:
char * Free format text string containing detailed status data

Returns:

TimLibError TimLibGetTelegram (  unsigned long  module,
TgmMachine  machine,
TgmTelegram *  telegram
) 
 

Read a machines telegram from a timing receiver. The module can be either zero, in which case the system decides which device to use, or it can be explicitly set between 1 and the number of installed modules. The telegram object returned has an opaque structure and can only be decoded through the Tgm library routine .....


unsigned long grval
grval = TgmGetGroupValueFromTelegram(unsigned long grnum, TgmTelegram *tgm)

If this routine is called by a users task, then it will actually call TgmGetTelegram to prevent multiple hardware accesses. By the way, this is much faster than a driver call as there is no PCI IO and no context switch, the telegram is read straight from sharded memory. Only when called by get_tgm_tim will a real hardware access be made. If a user task wants the telegram, the best way is to call tgm directly...


TgmTelegram telegram;
if (TgmGetTelegram(machine, index, offset, &telegram) == TgmSUCCESS) { ...

For more information on this function see the Tgm library man pages.

Parameters:
module Module from which you want to read the telegram, or 0 if don't care
machine The machine whose telegram you want to read
telegram Pointer to where the telegram will be stored
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibGetTgmInfo (  TimLibTime  stamp,
TimLibTime *  cyclestamp,
unsigned long *  cytag,
unsigned long *  ncytag
) 
 

Get telegram information from a time stamp. This routine searches the telegram history for a cycle in which your time stamp occured. It then returns the cycles time stamp in which the time you gave occurd and its present and next tags.

Parameters:
stamp Time you want telegram information about
cyclestamp Time of cycle for given stamp
cytag Present Cycle tag of cycle (NULL means ignore)
ncytag Next Cycle tag (NULL means ignore)
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibGetTime (  unsigned long  module,
TimLibTime *  utc
) 
 

Read the instantaneous value of the time in UTC. The module parameter can be set to zero in which case the system decideds which module to read the time from, otherwise it can be set to a value between 1 and the number of installed modules.

Parameters:
module Module number to read from, 0 means any module
utc Pointer to the time structure which will contain the time
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibInitialize (  TimLibDevice  device  ) 
 

This routine could have been hidden from the user of the Timing lib, however, in some circumstances, the initialization can take several minutes to complete. Hence I have decided to make an initialization routine publicly available, and force all applications/users to call it. This routine may perform the following initialization functions... 1) Opens a socket or a connection to a timing driver 2) Checks the Firmware/VHDL version against the latest revision Some EProms/FPGAs may need updating, this takes a while. 3) Load all relavent CTIM and PTIM definitions if needed. The device parameter specifies which type of device the library must use and initialize. If its set to ANY, the library will try to find a device by attempting to open each device driver in turn and in the order of the DEVICE enumeration: CTR_PCI,CTR_VME,TG8_CPS,TG8_SPS and finaly NETWORK.

Parameters:
device The device for which the library is to initialize
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibQueue (  unsigned long  qflag,
unsigned long  tmout
) 
 

Set queueing On or Off, and the time out value in micro seconds. A timeout value of zero means no time out, you wait for ever.

Parameters:
qflag The Queue Flag 0=>Queue, 1=>NoQueue
tmout The Timeout in microseconds, 0=> No timeout, waits for ever
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibRemoteControl (  unsigned long  remflg,
unsigned long  module,
unsigned long  cntr,
TimLibRemote  rcmd,
TimLibCcvMask  ccvm,
TimLibCcv *  ccv
) 
 

Set a counter under full remote control (IE under a DSC tasks' control) This feature permits you to do what you like with counters even if there is no timing cable attached. With this you can drive stepper motors, wire scanners or whatever. No PTIM or CTIM is involved, the configuration is loaded directly by the application. Note that when the argument remflg is set to 1, the counter can not be written to by incomming triggers so all PTIM objects using the counter stop overwriting the counter configuration and are effectivley disabled. Setting the remflg 0 permits PTIM triggers to write to the counter configuration, the write block is removed. Also note that in some cases it is useful to perform remote actions, such as remoteSTOP, even if the remflg is set to zero. The remflg simply blocks PTIM overwrites, the counter configuration can still be accessed !

Parameters:
remflg 0 = Normal, 1 = Remote
module The module number 1..n or zero selects also module 1
cntr The counter number 1..8 you are going to control
rcmd The remote command to execute on the counter
ccvm The CCV Mask containing field bits to be set
ccv Pointer to the CCV structure containing the fields to be set
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibSet (  unsigned long  ptim,
unsigned long  plnum,
unsigned long  grnum,
unsigned long  grval,
TimLibCcvMask  ccvm,
TimLibCcv *  ccv
) 
 

Set the PTIM actions. When plnum is non zero the triggers can be over written, in this case plnum indexes the PTIM object directly and the trigger is rebuilt using the machine, ctim, grnum, and grval fields in the ccv. The check mode is determind from the group descriptor via calls to the Tgm library.

Parameters:
ptim The PTIM equipment number you are going to set
plnum When modifying the trigger, this is the Ptim Line number 1..n, else 0
grnum The telegram group number or zero if no telegram check needed
grval The telegram group value needed to activate the trigger
ccvm The CCV Mask containing field bits to be set
ccv Pointer to the CCV structure containing the fields to be set
Returns:
TimLibError

void TimLibSetDebug (  unsigned long  level  ) 
 

Set the debug level, and also the behaviour of TimLibInitialize
Level 0 Normal behaviour, should be used when not debugging
Level 1 turns on diagnostic printing
Level 2 forces a re-initialization of the module in TimLibInitialize
Level 3 wipes out all PTIM and CTIM objects, starts with a clean slate
Level 4 is used in the SPS TG8s to keep actions created by other software
Level 5 updates VHDL or firmware

Example
TimLibSetDebug(3); Wipes out all PTIMS and CTIMS
err = TimLibInitialize(TimLibDevice_TG8_SPS); Start with a clean slate
if (err...

Parameters:
level The debug level 0..5 controling behaviour in initialization
Returns:
void

TimLibError TimLibSetOutputs (  TimLibLemo  output,
TimLibLemo  mask
) 
 

Special IO routine for CTR only, Set Counter Output LEMO values. By changing counter polarity you can change the counter outputs to 1 or 0. Counters not set in the supplied mask value do not change their output level.

Parameters:
output The counter output states
mask The counters whose output level you want to set
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibSetPllLocking (  unsigned long  module,
unsigned long  lockflag
) 
 

Control how the PLL locks after synchronization loss

Parameters:
module The module number 1..n of the timing receiver card
lockflag 1 implies Brutal 0 Slow PLL locking
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibSimulate (  TimLibClass  iclss,
unsigned long  equip,
unsigned long  module,
TgmMachine  machine,
unsigned long  grnum,
unsigned long  grval
) 
 

By writing to the driver this call simulates an interrupt for the connected clients. Also it can be used as a way of synchronizing processes, this is especially important in Linux systems where the schedular is not preemptive.

Parameters:
iclss Class of interrupt to simulate, PTIM, CTIM or Hardware
equip Equipment number for PTIM or CTIM, hardware mask for Hardware
module When class is CTIM or Hardware, the module number is used
machine Telegram ID is used for PTIM interrupts if grnum is not zero
grnum If zero, no telegram checking, else the PTIM triggers group number
grval The telegram group value for the PTIM trigger
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibStringToSlot (  char *  cyid,
unsigned long *  slix
) 
 

Convert a cycle Id string like CPS.USER.SFTPRO into a slot index. No abbreviations are supported, seperators are dots. Strict Syntax. The result is slix, the slot index ranging from [0..(GroupSize-1)]. No change is made to slix on error always check return before using.

Parameters:
cyid The Cycle ID string to parse
slix The Resulting slot index
Returns:
TimLibError

TimLibError TimLibWait (  TimLibClass *  iclss,
unsigned long *  equip,
unsigned long *  plnum,
TimLibHardware *  source,
TimLibTime *  onzero,
TimLibTime *  trigger,
TimLibTime *  start,
unsigned long *  ctim,
unsigned long *  payload,
unsigned long *  module,
unsigned long *  missed,
unsigned long *  qsize,
TgmMachine *  machine
) 
 

Wait for an interrupt. The parameters are all returned from the call so you can know which interrupt it was that came back. Note, when waiting for a hardware interrupt from either CTIM or from a counter, it is the CTIM or PTIM object that caused the interrupt returned. The telegram will have been read already by the high prioity task get_tgm_tim, be aware of the race condition here, hence payload. This routine is a blocking call, it waits for interrupt or timeout. Any NULL argument is permitted, and no value will be returned.

Parameters:
iclss The class of the interrupt CTIM, PTIM, or hardware
equip The PTIM, CTIM equipment, or hardware mask
plnum If class is PTIM this is the PLS line number
source The hardware source of the interrupt
onzero The time of the interrupt
trigger The arrival time of the event that triggered the action
start The time the start of the counter occured
ctim The CTIM equipment number of the triggering event
payload The payload of the triggering event
module The module number 1..n of the timing receiver card
missed The number of missed events since the last wait
qsize The number of remaining interrupts on the queue /*
machine The Tgm machine of the trigger event
Returns:
TimLibError
